content.description: A really nice slab is prominent on the same boulder as Juju’s arête. The climb is on the left of Juju’s arête. Side pulls, edges, balance moves, and a willingness to span out to the lip will lead to a sweet and easy top out. Very easy but worth doing being one of the obvious gems in the creek.
content.location: Same boulder that shares Juju’s arête. Hike down the creek from the pullout and the boulder will be to the right up the hill. Can’t miss it.

content.description:
The line originally starts in the obvious jug flake. The crux would be getting the right hand to the right side after throwing left hand to the left side of the arete off of the match start. Power moves short lived after hitting a block that will lead to the higher part of the arête. Good feet work will save you on the top out. Starting high with just hugging the arête would be around v1.

FUN FACT:  Before i actually sent it , the jug was a lot bigger with a similar horn feature on the top of the jug as the bottom portion. Now it’s just an edge and a horn on the bottom. While resting from working it my friend Casey who is double my size pulled on the flake, flew off and rolled down the hill. Pretty epic situation inspired me to send it next go with the newly formed hold. Boulder has been cleaned and ready to climb!
content.location: The boulder is visible from the pullout where the coordinates of the Middle San Juan Boulders are. After walking down to the creek, the boulder will be to the right up the hill and pretty obvious.
